description: Structural map of how child welfare authority is administered (state vs county vs hybrid) and how civil dependency proceedings run in parallel with criminal investigations. This plane determines who has decision authority and which legal standards apply at each decision node.

cw_system_administration.description: Administrative structure determines whether decision authority resides at the state or county level, directly affecting accountability, appeals, and policy uniformity.

categories.description: A single state agency operates child welfare statewide. Investigations, removals, and case management are conducted by state employees under centralized authority.

implications.funding_structure: Primarily state budget with federal reimbursement

categories.description: County agencies conduct investigations and case management under state supervision. Significant variation exists between counties.

implications.appeals_path: County process followed by state-level review
implications.funding_structure: State and county cost sharing with federal reimbursement

categories.description: Responsibilities are split between state and county agencies depending on function (e.g., county investigations with state case management).

implications.appeals_path: Depends on which entity made the decision

cw_system_administration.training_note: Accurate answers to 'who decides' require knowing whether the system is state- or county-administered. The term 'the agency' is jurisdiction-dependent.

criminal_civil_parallel.description: Child welfare matters routinely involve parallel civil dependency proceedings and criminal investigations, each governed by different standards, rights, and outcomes.

tracks.purpose: Protect the child and determine custody, placement, and services

legal_standards.termination_of_parental_rights: Clear and convincing evidence (Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982))

rights.right_to_counsel: Not constitutionally guaranteed; case-by-case determination (Lassiter v. DSS, 452 U.S. 18 (1981))
rights.fifth_amendment: Limited; adverse inference from silence may be permitted in some jurisdictions

tracks.purpose: Punish offenders and protect public safety

when_applies: Abuse on federal lands or facilities

interaction_points.constitutional_risk: Statements may be used criminally without Miranda warnings
interaction_points.best_practice: Coordinate CPS and law enforcement interviews; provide clear warnings when prosecution is foreseeable

interaction_points.constitutional_risk: Coerced consent invalid under Fourth Amendment
interaction_points.best_practice: Obtain voluntary consent or judicial authorization

fifth_amendment_key_cases.name: Lefkowitz v. Cunningham
fifth_amendment_key_cases.holding: State may not impose substantial penalties for exercising Fifth Amendment privilege

fifth_amendment_key_cases.name: Baltimore City Dept. of Social Services v. Bouknight
fifth_amendment_key_cases.holding: Production of a child pursuant to a valid custody order is not testimonial, but Fifth Amendment protections against compelled testimony remain

implications_for_training: Always identify administrative structure before answering authority questions
Distinguish civil dependency rights from criminal procedural rights
Warn parents of criminal exposure during CPS investigations
Do not generalize practices across county-administered states
